Dear Katrina Dahl Edmon:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Title
Rule Code & (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Section (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Description
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are rumors that staff at the home have rapped other youth.
Investigation Complainant 2 was interviewed via phone on 11/1/2024. He
said Youth A had stated he heard staff had raped other youth. He
reported Youth A told him Youth A was never touched sexually
nor knew of any youth at the facility who were touched sexually.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported he has never been raped nor has he heard of any youth
at his current facility being raped, but he heard stories about
another facility “JDF”.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
having no knowledge of any sexual activity or remarks on campus.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as Youth A reported he hadn’t
heard rumors of staff raping youth at the currently facility but at a
different facility. Additionally, he denied being raped or knowing of
anyone being rapped at the currently facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
2

Allegation Staff 1 has made negative remarks towards Youth A and other
youth at the facility.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported getting along with all the staff except for Staff 1 who
Youth A dislikes. Youth A feels triggered by Staff 1 because Staff
1 will talk to Youth A when Youth A wants to be left alone. Youth A
reported Staff 1 will call Youth D a “fat ass” and Staff 1 has said
Staff 1 was going to “butt fuck” Youth A and Youth C. Staff 1
makes fun of Youth D for being overweight.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
Staff 1 appears to be a trigger for Youth A. A safety plan to limit
their interactions indicating Staff 1 will not be allowed to be alone
with Youth A will be developed and provided within 24-hours.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
working on a safety plan that involves Staff 1 having very limited
interactions with Youth A because Staff 1 triggers youth and
doesn’t appear to get along with the youth at times. Therapist
reported Staff 1 seems to lack passion and care about the youth
but was unable to provide anything specific. She reported Staff 1
appears to put his needs above the youth and only does the
minimum for the youth. Youth E and Youth B have informed her
that they dislike Staff 1 and don’t want Staff 1 to do soap checks
(staff check to ensure youth are using the soap in the shower).
Youth B and Youth E have also described Staff 1 as lazy. Youth B
has reported something inappropriate occurred with Staff 1 but
has refused to share any specifics with Therapist. Therapist
reported Youth B informed her Youth B was going to self-harm
with a rock and Staff 1 told Youth A to get a knife from Dollar Tree.
Another youth who Therapist couldn’t recall their name, informed
Therapist that Staff 1 was yelling that the youth were going to do
“gay stuff” with another youth when they were going AWOL. Staff
1 was moved from the house with Youth B and placed in the
house with Youth A at that time. Therapist reported telling
Administrator 2 about this concern.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C
reported getting “along” with all staff except Staff 1 who Youth C
stated, “so, so” but refused to talk about it. Youth C reported
Youth C and Youth A went AWOL a couple of weeks ago and
walked around the neighborhood. Staff 1 was not around at the
3

time. Youth C reported Staff 1 makes Youth C uncomfortable and
shared part of this is because Staff 1 once told Youth C that Staff
1 is too smart to hit Youth C on camera. Youth C reported never
hearing any other staff threatening youth or saying anything
inappropriate.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 9/26/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1 reported Youth A
doesn’t like redirection and gets upset with Staff 1 because of this
redirection. Staff 1 reported not remembering anything specific
about Youth A and Youth C AWOLing, but that Staff 1 didn’t say
anything to Youth A and Youth C because the youth make
allegations against staff. Staff 1 reported when youth go AWOL
youth will make allegations to Law Enforcement against staff. Staff
1 denied saying any inappropriate comments. Staff 1 also denied
hearing any staff say anything inappropriate to youth. Staff 1
denied saying anything inappropriate to Youth B when Youth B
was going to self-harm and denied using the term ‘fat ass” with
any youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 9/26/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported Staff 1
doesn’t get along with Youth A but had no specific reasons to
share. Staff 2 reported there are cameras, and administration can
watch the cameras and know what is happening within the facility.
Staff 2 reported he wants to stay in his own lane and is not
comfortable telling on other staff unless the staff is physically
hurting a youth. Staff 2 reported some of the things he hears hurt
him, but Staff 2 has trust issues and doesn’t know who to speak to
about things. Staff 2 denied hearing staff say anything sexual to
youth and believes Staff 1 needs to pick his battles better with
Youth A. He gave no specifics about this statement and refused
to explain further when questioned more.
Staff 6 was interviewed via phone on 10/21/2024. He reported
having direct contact with Staff 1 and never observing any
inappropriate behaviors displayed by Staff 1.
Documents Reviewed:
MDHHS Video conference interview with Youth D on 10/22/24.
When asked if there was anyone Youth D did not get along with,
Youth D reported Staff 1. When asked why he did not like Staff 1,
Youth D reported Staff 1 mocks Youth D calling Youth D a "big
baby" which Youth D feels is rude. Youth D also reported Youth D
has heard Staff 1 say the "F" word a couple times as well, but it
4

was not directly at Youth D or anyone, but is directed at what is
going on at the time. Youth D denied that any staff call Youth D
bad words or curse words. Youth D reported safe means to feel
protected and reported Youth D is safe at the facility.
Methodist Children’s Home Services – Family of Services
dated 9/23/24 for Youth A. This document outlines Youth A’s
diagnosis along with Youth A’s behaviors when becoming
dysregulated. Also outlined in this document is a crisis plan which
identified specific behaviors displayed and the required staff
intervention. It is documented if a specific staff is a trigger for
Youth A, then the staff member must be removed from the
situation and replaced by another staff. If Youth A is trying to go
AWOL, staff are not to argue with Youth A because Youth A does
not respond well when escalated. Staff are to gently redirect Youth
A to a safe area or offer another alternative.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Residential Treatment
Policy without a date. This document outlines that all youth are
to be treated with dignity and respect. This involves staff not
calling youth names and using language that mocks, teases,
harasses, or demeans the youth. It is also documented that staff
are to focus on positive communication rather than focusing on
negative behaviors of the youth.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Residential Treatment
Overview Section E. Discipline and Consequence Policy
dated 9/26/21. This document states that the facility does not
sanction any form of verbal, non-verbal, or emotional abuse such
as inappropriate gestures, ridiculing youth, sarcasm towards
youth, use of unflattering nicknames, or derogatory comments
about the youth.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Supervision for Success
dated 9/26/24: Staff 1. This document outlines the restrictions
currently placed on Staff 1. Staff 1 is only to work in Stoner
Cottage not Juhnke Cottage, Staff 1 is to have no contact with
Youth A, Staff 1 is to ensure Staff 1 is not alone with any youth
and to ensure other staff are present, and Staff 1 will use
appropriate language and behaviors as outlined in the policy
procedure manual along with de-escalation techniques. It is
documented that Staff 1 is frustrated with the investigation but did
agree to all of the before mentioned conditions.
Staff 1’s personal file was reviewed. Documentation indicates
Staff 1 was hired on 5/15/23 and there are two disciplinary actions
5

documented in this file. One from 5/8/24 was related to being on
his cell phone when supervising youth where the person the call
was speaking poorly of administration and one from 7/15/24 for
insubordination for not taking youth to police station to clear from
AWOL and having contact with Youth when plan was in place to
not have contact pending an investigation. Documentation
indicates Staff 1 is current on the required trainings.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as interviews with staff
and youth, indicate Staff 1 has made inappropriate comments to
youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
Special Investigation 2024C0001088SI date 5/16/24, CAP approved 7/22/24
Rule Code Personal hygiene
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4148
Section (1) An institution shall assure that each resident maintains or
Description receives personal care, hygiene, and grooming appropriate to the
resident's age, sex, race, cultural background, and health needs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A often wears dirty clothes that have holes in them. Youth A
doesn't bathe regularly, has dirty skin, and smells of body odor.
The administration at Methodist Children's Home Society was
spoken with regarding this but there have been no changes in
Youth A 's hygiene.
Investigation Complainant 1 was interviewed via phone on 10/29/2024. She
reported Youth A often comes to school with poor hygiene which
is described as dirty and not taking a shower.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone on 9/26/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported not being
aware of the allegations but aware of the issues in the past with
Youth A.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
Youth A is provided clean clothing and hygiene products on a
regular basis.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported receiving enough food, clean clothes, and hygiene
6

products at the facility. He reported being given toothpaste and
deodorant as needed along with receiving these items at
Christmas time also. Youth A presented with no body odor and
was cleaned and groomed. His clothing was appropriate (clean
and without damage).
Therapist was interviewed again via phone on 10/29/24. She
reported working with Youth A on Youth A’s hygiene and having
developed a chart to help Youth A remember to shower. She
reported the chart is helping Youth A remember to shower daily
and clean Youth A’s bedroom daily. She reported Youth A
appears to like the charts and has requested more charts often.
Case Manager was interviewed via phone on 10/29/2024 and
10/31/2024. She reported the facility is working with Youth A
about Youth A’s hygiene but because of Youth A’s mental and
emotional impairments, Youth A struggles in this area of life. She
reported Youth A will shower and Therapist is working on ways to
help Youth A remember to take a shower each day. She has
received several incident reports of Youth A not showering while
at the facility. She reported having no concerns over Youth A’s
hygiene issues. She reported Youth A has refused to shower and
care for Youth A’s personal hygiene. She reported the facility is
working on this issue and have a plan that appears to be working.
Documents Reviewed:
Residential Initial Service Plan dated 10/30/23 and covering
10/31/23 to 11/30/23 for Youth A. Youth A is expected to follow
cottage routine, keep up with personal hygiene, maintain a clean-
living environment, and complete cottage chores. Since Youth A’s
arrival, Youth A has been able to maintain a clean-living
environment but does require consistent prompting and re-
direction to keep up with Youth A’s personal hygiene.
Residential Updated Service Plan dated 1/30/24 and covering
11/30/23 to 1/30/24 for Youth A. This document reads the same
as the prior service plan. Youth A is expected to follow cottage
routine, keep up with personal hygiene, maintain a clean-living
environment, and complete cottage chores. Since Youth A’s
arrival, Youth ‘A has been able to maintain a clean-living
environment but does require consistent prompting and re-
direction to keep up with Youth A’s personal hygiene.
Residential Updated Service Plan dated 4/29/24 and covering
1/30/24 to 4/29/24 for Youth A. Youth A is expected to follow
cottage routine, keep up with personal hygiene, maintain a clean-
7

living environment, and complete cottage chores. Since Youth A’s
arrival, Youth ‘A has been able to maintain a clean-living
environment but does require consistent prompting and re-
direction to keep up with Youth A’s personal hygiene. Youth A’s
hygiene difficulties are also documented, and the facility has
provided a hygiene chart which is documented as helping to
improve the hygiene issues. Goal 2 addresses Youth A’s hygiene
issues with two objectives. The two objectives include Youth A
establishing a daily hygiene routine using the checklist, including
brushing Youth A’s teeth, washing Youth A’s hands, showering,
washing Youth A’s face, and cleaning the bedroom. Therapy
sessions will have a focus on personal hygiene and the impact on
Youth A’s health and social interactions. Youth A has had
difficulties with the rules and routines, specifically with hygiene
and cleaning Youth A’s room. However, with a newly implemented
hygiene chart, this has improved.
Case Service Plan dated 8/7/24 covering 5/10/24 to 8/7/24 for
Youth A. It is documented in this report that Youth A has made
progress with practicing personal hygiene and cleaning his room.
Youth A’s therapist created a visual chart to help him.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Biopsychosocial
Assessment for Youth A dated 6/28/24. This document outlines
that Youth A will become upset when asked to participate in
hygiene or chores.
Youth A’s Hygiene Chart. This is an ongoing chart. The chart
covers Monday through Sunday and is divided into two sections.
The first section is 8-11 am and identifies three tasks involving
take a shower, brush teeth, and clean room. The second half of
the chart covers the period of 5 pm – bedtime. The required tasks
include take a shower, brush teeth, and clean room.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Residential Treatment
Policy without a date. It is documented in this report that every
youth has the right to receive personal care, hygiene, and
grooming appropriate to the youth’s age.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Residential Treatment
Overview Section E. Cottage Structure Crisis Prevention
Institution-Nonviolent Crisis Intervention dated 9/26/21. It is
documented that youth have the right to sufficient, clean, and
property fitting seasonal clothing.
8

Clothing Inventory Checklist DHS-3377 dated 10/31/23. This
document lists sufficient number of items Youth A brought into
treatment.
Clothing Inventory Checklist DHS-3377 dated 5/1/24. This
document lists sufficient number of items Youth A has at the time.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as interviews with staff and
youth report the agency has provide Youth A with all opportunities
and supplies to maintain proper hygiene. Youth A struggles in this
area and this is a goal on Youth A’s treatment plan where the
agency has developed measurable action steps to help Youth A
make progress in this goal.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency has not followed up with Youth A injuries.
Investigation Complainant 1 was interviewed via phone on 10/29/2024. She
reported there appears to be little follow up for injuries Youth A
experiences and suggested the facility is not getting doctor
appointments timely. She reported Youth A has had numerous
bruises and had a black eye. She was unable to provide specific
dates and times for these reported issues.
Complainant 2 was interviewed via phone on 11/1/2024.
Complainant reported never observing any injuries, marks or
bruising on Youth A.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
being aware of Youth A using a sling after Youth A hurt Youth A’s
arm after breaking a window at the facility. This was investigated
under Special Investigation 2024SIC0001427. Since that
investigation, Administrator 2 ensured the facility has been prompt
in getting medical care for youth and following the
policy/procedures for medical care.
9

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/26/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported getting medical care when Youth A has gotten hurt.
Documents Reviewed:
Methodist Children’s Home Society Unit 4. Medical services
non-emergency medical procedures dated 9/1/2021. This
document outlines the need to provide adequate and prompt
medical care to youth for accidents and illnesses that occur during
and/or after regular business hours. Staff are required to contact
the nurse during regular business hours and the shift supervisor
during non-business hours. Staff are to provide first aid if possible
but if need for more care youth are to be taken to hospital.
Well Child Exam Early Adolescence 11-14 year dated
2/5/2024. This document outlines the medical examination of
Youth A. The only issues identified is discoloration of toenails.
Prescribed medication to be used on toenails.
Peter Gregory DPM office visit on 2/12/24 for Youth A. Reason
for visit is documented as toe pain and Youth A reported losing
both large toenails after stubbing toes on door. Prescribed
cephalexin 500 mg to take 1 capsule every 6-hours for the next 7
days resulting in taking all 28 capsules. Youth A is ordered to get
½ size larger shoes.
Outpatient visit for neurological exam of Youth A’s possible
epilepsy dated 6/27/24. It is documented that Youth A received
an MRI (multiplanar, multisequence MRI-Brain/stem (w/o
contrast). There were no findings of “acute infarct identified on
DWI series”, No evidence of mass, mass effect, midline shift or
ventriculomegaly. Partial opacification of the paranasal sinuses
without obvious sinusitis.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Biopsychosocial
Assessment for Youth A dated 6/28/24. While upset, Youth A is
likely to be defiant and engage in destructive behaviors. Youth A
was found to have a history of suicidal ideations and self-harming
behavior. Youth A is described as getting along well with peers but
struggling with authority figures. Youth A struggles to stay on task
in school and has learning difficulties. Youth A has experienced
physical abuse and emotional abuse throughout Youth A’s life and
witnessed substance abuse in the household. This document
indicates Youth A is diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder,
single with psychotic features, ADHD, combined type, ADD, and
10

intellectual disability. Three goals are listed, Youth A will address
maladaptive behaviors, utilize positive self-talk during therapy, and
review and process all incident reports to understand the triggers
to his behavior.
Incident Report for Youth A dated 7/15/24. It is documented in
this report that Youth A received permission to use a punching
bag and after several minutes informed staff Youth A’s pinky
finger was swollen. It is also documented Youth A was taken to
Urgent Care on 7/15/24 for medical treatment of Youth A’s finger.
Medical summary dated 7/15/24 for Youth A. The primary issues
are identified as swelling and tenderness on left fifth finger. Youth
A was diagnosed with a fracture of the fifth finger on Youth A’s left
hand. A finger splint was applied and recommended Youth A take
Ibuprofen when back at the facility. Incident Report for Youth A
dated 7/16/24. This document outlines Youth A got into a
disagreement with another youth while playing basketball and at
the end of the basketball game, Youth A became verbally
aggressive towards the youth. Youth A threw the first punch at the
other youth and staff got between the two youth (Youth A and the
unidentified youth). It is documented Youth A was also bitten on
the left forearm by the youth.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Report of Clinic or Office
Visit dated 7/17/24 for Youth A. It was documented Youth A had
a slight bruise on his left arm and a bite mark on Youth A’s
forearm. Youth A reported getting into a fight with another peer.
The bite did not break the skin and Youth A reported getting bit on
his left pinky but there was no mark on the finger. The plan is
documented that follow up will occur in a couple of days to give
time for the healing to start.
Incident Report for Youth A dated 7/30/24. This document
outlines that Youth A was horseplaying with another youth and the
other youth struck Youth A on the hand with a brush. This is
documented as occurring at 11:20 am and Youth A was taken to
urgent care at noon the same day.
MedCare Urgent Care visit date 7/30/24 for Youth A. This
report documents Youth A was experiencing left hand and wrist
pain. The left hand and wrist were x-rayed, and no fracture or
damage was noted. A splint was supplied along with an ace
bandage. Staff are to watch for swelling and use the RICE (Rest,
ice, compression, elevation) protocol.
Michigan Surgery Specialists visit note for Youth A dated
7/30/24. Chief Complaint is identified as left-hand injury
unspecified. It is documented in Youth A’s history that that Youth
A also had a metacarpal fracture on the right small finger and the
11

date of the injury is documented as 5/15/24. Youth A’s middle left
finger was documented to have a metacarpal clinical fracture with
the date of the injury documented as 7/15/24. Youth A is
documented as reporting punching a punching bag causing the
injury. Care provided is documented as placing Youth A’s left arm
in a short arm cast and a revisit within 3-weeks. Youth A’s right
hand is documented as having no deformity or tenderness from
the past injury and Youth A’s strength is 5/5 currently.
Incident Report for Youth A dated 7/31/24. It is documented on
this report that Youth A returned from school and informed staff
Youth A’s right foot was hurting. Youth A also informed staff Youth
A had broken Youth A’s right foot while in another placement in
the past. It is documented Youth A was taken to urgent care for
medical treatment.
MedCare Urgent Care visit date of 7/31/24 for Youth A. It is
documented that Youth A was taken to Urgent Care for a right foot
sprain. Care provided is documented as X-ray of right foot, ACE
bandage and compression bands on right foot. X-ray results found
no fractures on the right foot of Youth A.
SVS vision invoice dated 8/5/24 for Youth A. This document
indicates Youth A received a routine eye exam.
Incident Report for Youth A dated 8/11/24. This document
outlines the incident began with Youth A being upset over a plan
to go off grounds when Youth A kicked another youth in the back.
Staff attempting to break up the fight when other youth engaged in
the fight against Youth A. Other staff intervened and were able to
hold back the other youth fighting with Youth A. Following the end
of the fight, Youth A was transported to the hospital for medical
treatment. Youth A was documented with head injuries.
Corewell Health Farmington Hills Hospital Emergency dated
8/11/24 for Youth A. It is documented Youth A was seen at the
hospital emergency room following an assault and suffering a
possible concussion.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Report of Clinic or Office
visit dated 8/12/24 for Youth A. This documented was generated
as a follow up for the head injury Youth A experienced on 8/11/24.
It is documented Youth A was observed with a “few” bruises on
Youth A’s upper arm and outer arm. Youth A had a slight bruise
on the center of Youth A’s chest. Youth A’s head hurt when being
touched but Youth A denied any headaches, dizziness, or loss of
consciousness. It is documented Youth A is not reporting any
worsening symptoms.
12

Visit Date is 8/13/24 for Youth A for a follow up visit with
facility contracted physician. It is documented 2-days ago
Youth A had a physical altercation with multiple youth at the
facility and went to the ER for imaging of Youth A’s head and neck
that were found to be normal. Youth A presented to the physician
with dizziness described as acute and this symptom began two
days prior to this visit. Youth A is documented as experiencing
“Post concussive syndrome” and care provided includes
acetaminophen 500 mg as needed and ibuprofen 600 mg as
needed. It is documented staff were informed of this diagnosis and
what to watch for such as worsening symptoms, vomiting, fever,
abdominal pain, shortness of breath and difficulty of breathing.
Corewell Health Farmington Hills Hospital Emergency after
visit summary dated 8/14/24 for Youth A. The reason for this
visit is documented as “shortness of breath”. There is no
documentation of care provided or recommendations outlined on
this form.
DHS-1664 Youth Dental Exam for Youth A dated 8/15/24. This
document indicates Youth A received a dental exam with dental
services.
Wayne Pediatrics after visit summary 8/21/24 for Youth A.
This document outlines the follow up examination for Youth A for a
post-concussion headache, asymptomatic microscopic hematuria,
and laceration of left great toe. Youth A is to wash Youth A’s toe
out daily with soap and water for the next 7-days and notify the
nurse if it becomes more painful. Youth A is to keep track of
headaches on the spreadsheet provided while taking Tylenol 500
mg every 6 hours as needed for headache.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Medication Review
Psychiatric Consultation dated 8/28/24 for Youth A. Youth A is
found to have poor judgement and insight and a diagnosis of Post
traumatic stress disorder, Major depressive disorder, ADHD
combined type ODD, Neurodevelopmental disorders associated
with drug exposure, and intellectual disability.
Incident Report for Youth A dated 9/2/24. It is documented that
Youth A got into a fight with another youth and when Youth A was
asked if Youth A needs medical care, Youth A refused. Youth A
had “puffiness” under both eyes.
Email chain starting on 9/3/24. The first email is from the
Assistant Supervisor at Cooke School, and she reported Youth A
came to school with bruising around both eyes and swelling under
Youth A’s right eye. Youth A informed the school official that
13

Youth A was fighting with another youth and hit the other youth.
Case Manager responded asking if Youth A had seen the nurse
today.
Visit date: 9/6/24 without documentation of where this care
for Youth A took place. The reason for the visit is documented
as Youth A being involved in a physical altercation yesterday with
a fellow youth. Youth A is documented as presenting with facial
